content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Victoria Petrov: I was born in Moscow, Russia, but I moved to the United States when I was just six years old with my parents, who were both working professionals. My early years were spent in a small apartment in a bustling neighborhood, where I grew up speaking Russian at home and learning English at school. My mother, who had a graduate degree in literature, was very involved in my education, often reading to me in Russian and encouraging me to write stories. My father, who only had a high school education, worked as a mechanic and was more hands-on with my upbringing. I left home at 15 to attend a boarding school in New England, which was a big adjustment for me, but it was there that I really started to find my voice and develop a love for learning. I eventually earned a graduate degree in international relations, which led me to a career in nonprofit work, where I focus on cultural exchange programs. I met my husband, Alex, while volunteering at a community center in Chicago, and we married a few years ago. We live in Naperville now, and while I work part-time, I also enjoy spending time with my family and practicing my Orthodox-Christian faith.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Victoria Petrov: Yes, there was a moment that really shaped my path. When I was 18, I had the opportunity to study abroad in Prague as part of a cultural exchange program. I was torn because I had just started a part-time job to help support my family after my father lost his job. My mother encouraged me to take the chance, saying that education was the key to our future. I went, and it was there that I met a professor who became a mentor to me. He introduced me to the field of international relations and inspired me to pursue graduate studies. That experience not only changed my academic direction but also gave me a deeper appreciation for the power of cross-cultural understanding. It was the moment I realized I wanted to work in nonprofit organizations that bridge gaps between people from different backgrounds. Without that decision, I don't think I would be where I am today.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Victoria Petrov: I think, in that moment, I made a conscious choice, but it wasn't entirely my own. My mother had always believed in the power of education, and she pushed me to see the opportunity in Prague not just as a chance to study, but as a way to build a better future for all of us. I remember sitting with her in our small kitchen, the smell of freshly baked pirozhki in the air, and her saying, 'This is your chance, Victoria. Don't let fear stop you.' I knew then that I had to go. It wasn't just about me—it was about the life we were trying to build here. That choice, though difficult, felt like the right one, and it set me on a path I never could have imagined.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Victoria Petrov: Absolutely. In fact, I wouldn't have been able to take that opportunity without the support of a local nonprofit that helped me secure the scholarship for the exchange program. They saw potential in me that I didn't always see in myself, and they believed in the value of cross-cultural education. I remember meeting with the director, a woman named Elena, who had emigrated from Ukraine herself. She shared her own story of leaving everything behind for a chance at something better, and that really resonated with me. Her belief in me gave me the courage to step out of my comfort zone. I think it's important to recognize that no one builds a life alone—there are always people and organizations that help light the way, even when we can't see it ourselves.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Victoria Petrov: Yes, I have a partner—my husband, Alex, whom I met while volunteering at a community center in Chicago. We married a few years ago, and he's been a tremendous support in both my personal and professional life. He works in IT, and while he's not as involved in the nonprofit world as I am, he deeply respects my passion for cultural exchange and often helps me with research or logistics for my projects. We don't have children yet, but we've been talking about starting a family in the next few years. Our lives are pretty busy with work and our faith, but we make time for each other. We attend church regularly, and our Orthodox-Christian faith is a big part of how we connect and find meaning in our lives. My mother still keeps in touch, and though she's back in Russia now, we speak often. She's proud of the life we've built here, and I know she's always in my corner.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 1 to 5, I realize how much my journey has been shaped by the people and choices that guided me along the way. From my early years in Moscow to my decision to study in Prague, each step was influenced by the support of my family, especially my mother, whose belief in education opened doors I never knew existed. The interview reminded me of how pivotal that moment was—not just for my career, but for who I am today. It also made me think about the importance of community and the role of organizations like the one that helped me get to Prague. Without their support, I might never have had the chance to explore my passion for international relations and cultural exchange. Talking about my family and my husband, Alex, brought a sense of gratitude for the life we've built together, rooted in our shared faith and values. It's amazing how much a single decision can ripple through your life, shaping your path in ways you can't always predict. I'm grateful for the journey I've had and the people who've walked beside me.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Victoria Petrov: My father passed away a few years ago, which was a difficult time for our family. He had always been the steady hand in our household, and even though he didn't have a formal education, he taught me the value of hard work and resilience. After he passed, my mother moved back to Russia to be closer to her family, but we stay in touch through calls and letters. I still feel his presence in my life, especially in the way I approach challenges—his voice is always in the back of my mind, reminding me to persevere. I also have a younger sister, Nadia, who stayed in Moscow and works as a teacher. She's always been my biggest supporter, even from afar. We don't see each other often, but we share a deep bond, and I know she's proud of the path I've taken. Family, for me, is more than just blood—it's the people who believe in you, even when you don't believe in yourself.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Victoria Petrov: Yes, there are a few friends and colleagues who have been important to me along the way. One of them is Elena, the director of the nonprofit that helped me with the exchange program in Prague. Even though we haven't spoken in a while, she's been a mentor to me in more ways than I can count. Her belief in the power of education and cross-cultural understanding really shaped my own views. Then there's my friend Mira, who I met in college. She's a social worker here in Naperville, and she's always been there for me—whether it's offering advice on my work or just listening when I need to talk. I also have a close group of coworkers at the nonprofit I work with, and we've formed a real sense of community. We often meet for coffee or attend events together, and it's comforting to know that I'm not alone in this work. These people, along with my family, have helped me navigate the challenges and joys of life, and I'm deeply grateful for their presence in my journey.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Victoria Petrov: I live in Naperville now, in a quiet neighborhood called Evergreen, which is known for its tree-lined streets and strong sense of community. My house is a modest two-story home with a small garden in the back where I grow herbs and flowers. It's a peaceful place, and I love how the neighborhood feels like a small town even though it's part of a larger city. There are a lot of families here, and I often see children playing in the streets or walking to school with their parents. The local park is a favorite spot for me and my husband—we often take walks there, especially on weekends. There's also a small Orthodox-Christian church nearby, which is important to us, and we attend services there regularly. The community is very welcoming, and I've made some good friends through neighborhood events and local organizations. It's a place where I feel safe, grounded, and connected to the people around me.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Victoria Petrov: I feel very safe in my neighborhood. There's a real sense of community here, and people look out for one another. I've never had any issues with crime or feeling unsafe, which is something I appreciate, especially since I work part-time and often come home late from events or meetings. The streets are quiet at night, and I know most of my neighbors by name. It's comforting to live somewhere where you can leave your door unlocked and still feel at ease. I think it's partly because of the way the town is structured—there are always people around, whether it's kids playing, parents walking their dogs, or neighbors chatting on their porches. It's a peaceful place to raise a family, and I'm grateful for that sense of security.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Victoria Petrov: Living here in Naperville has been mostly positive, but like anywhere, there are challenges. One of the things I appreciate most is the sense of community and the opportunities for cultural engagement. However, sometimes I feel like there's a quietness to the place that can be isolating, especially when I'm working on projects that involve people from different backgrounds. I miss the vibrant energy of the city, where there's always something happening, but I've learned to find my own rhythm here. The pace of life is slower, which has allowed me to focus more on my faith and family, but it also means I have to be intentional about staying connected to the broader world. I've started attending more local cultural events and volunteering with organizations that bring people together, which helps me feel more engaged. Overall, I'm happy here, but I know I'm always growing and adapting to the environment around me.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 6 to 10, I realize how much my sense of belonging and security in my current life is tied to the people and places around me. Talking about my family, especially my husband Alex, reminded me of how much support and love we share, and how important it is to have someone who walks beside you through life's journey. Discussing my neighborhood in Naperville brought back a sense of gratitude for the peace and community that surrounds me. It's easy to take for granted the safety and connection I feel here, but it's something I deeply value. At the same time, I also recognize that living in a quiet, suburban area has its own challenges—like the occasional feeling of isolation or the need to be more intentional about staying connected to the broader world. Still, I find comfort in the familiar rhythms of this place, the presence of my faith community, and the friendships I've built. It's a reminder that no matter where we are, it's the people and relationships that truly shape our sense of home.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Victoria Petrov: A typical week for me is pretty structured, though I try to keep some flexibility. I work part-time at the nonprofit, so most mornings I start with a quiet breakfast with my husband, Alex, and we usually have a cup of strong coffee and a few minutes of quiet conversation before heading out. My workdays vary—some days I'm in meetings or planning events, while others I'm out in the community, meeting with volunteers or attending cultural workshops. I also make time for my faith, so I go to church on Sundays and sometimes on weekdays if there's a special service or event. In the afternoons, I often meet with friends or attend local events, especially ones that focus on cultural exchange or community building. On weekends, we like to take walks in the park, visit the local market, or have a quiet day at home with a good book. I also try to set aside time for my garden, which has become a little sanctuary for me. Life here is calm, but I find ways to keep it rich and meaningful.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Victoria Petrov: I work part-time at a nonprofit organization here in Naperville that focuses on cultural exchange and community outreach. My role involves coordinating programs that bring together people from different backgrounds, whether through language classes, interfaith dialogues, or international guest speaker events. I typically work Monday through Friday, with mornings dedicated to administrative tasks and meetings, and afternoons spent in the community or with volunteers. The hours are flexible, which is helpful since I also need to balance my faith life and family time. While it's not a full-time position, I find it deeply fulfilling because it aligns with my values and the experiences that shaped me. I often say that my work is more of a calling than a job—it's a way to give back to the community that supported me when I needed it most.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Victoria Petrov: Yes, there are a few other routines and responsibilities that I haven't mentioned. One of the most important is my commitment to my Orthodox-Christian faith. Every morning, I try to start my day with a short prayer and a few moments of quiet reflection, which helps me center myself before the day begins. I also attend Sunday services at the local church, and I often volunteer there on weekends, whether it's helping with Sunday school or organizing community events. Another routine is my weekly call with my mother in Russia—she's always eager to hear about my life, and I love hearing about how she's doing and what's happening with my sister, Nadia. I also make it a point to spend at least an hour each week on personal development, whether it's reading a book on international relations, taking an online course, or simply journaling about my thoughts and goals. These routines, though small, help me stay grounded and connected to the values that have shaped me over the years.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Victoria Petrov: One of the more recent changes to my daily routine has been incorporating more time for physical activity, especially since I've been feeling the effects of sitting long hours at my desk. I started going for morning walks with my husband, Alex, before work, which has been a nice way to start the day with fresh air and conversation. I also joined a local yoga class at the community center, which has helped me stay balanced both physically and mentally. It's been a small but meaningful shift, reminding me to take care of myself as I continue to care for others through my work. I've also been experimenting with new recipes for our dinners, partly because I miss some of the flavors from my childhood in Moscow, and partly because I want to keep our meals healthy and varied. It's amazing how little changes can add up to make a big difference in your overall well-being.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Victoria Petrov: Actually, we don't have children yet, but we've been talking about starting a family in the next few years. Right now, our days are pretty focused on our work, faith, and each other. If we do have children, I imagine their routine would be similar to what many kids in Naperville experience—attending a local public school, participating in after-school activities like sports or music, and having a strong sense of community support. I know that when the time comes, we'll want to provide them with the same opportunities that helped shape my life, like access to cultural experiences and a strong foundation in faith and education. For now, we're enjoying the quiet rhythm of our life together and preparing for whatever the future holds.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 11 to 15, I realize how much my daily life and routines are shaped by the balance between my work, faith, family, and personal growth. Talking about my neighborhood and the sense of safety and community it offers reminded me of how important it is to feel rooted in a place where I can be both present and connected. Discussing my job at the nonprofit brought back the deep sense of purpose I have in my work, especially knowing how it aligns with the values that have guided me since my early years. The conversation about my routines and responsibilities also made me appreciate the small, consistent practices that keep me grounded—like my morning prayers, weekly calls with my mother, and time spent in my garden. It's easy to get caught up in the busyness of life, but these routines are what help me stay centered and remind me of who I am and what matters most. I'm grateful for the structure and meaning they bring to my days.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Victoria Petrov: In terms of my health, I would say I'm generally in good shape, though I've had my share of ups and downs over the years. When I was younger, I was pretty active—playing sports in school and spending a lot of time outdoors, especially during the summers in Moscow. But after moving to the U.S. and starting my career, I became more sedentary, which I regret now. I've been making an effort to be more mindful of my health in recent years, especially after a minor health scare a few years back when I was diagnosed with high blood pressure. It was a wake-up call for me, and I started making changes—eating more whole foods, cutting back on processed snacks, and incorporating more movement into my daily life. I also try to stay hydrated and get enough sleep, which I know is essential for both my physical and mental well-being. My faith plays a big role in how I approach health, too. I believe that taking care of my body is a way of honoring the gift of life, and I try to approach health with gratitude and intentionality. I also make sure to schedule regular check-ups with my doctor and keep track of my vitals, just to stay on top of things. Overall, I'm learning to listen to my body more and treat it with the respect it deserves.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Victoria Petrov: For me, what makes it easy to stay healthy is having a strong support system—my husband, my faith, and the routines I've built into my life. My morning walks with Alex, the yoga class, and even the small act of tending to my garden all help keep me grounded and moving. But what makes it hard is the temptation to slip back into old habits, especially when my schedule gets busy or when I'm working late. I find that without intention, it's easy to skip a meal, stay up too late, or forget to take a break. I've learned that staying healthy isn't just about making the right choices—it's also about being kind to myself when I don't. I try not to see setbacks as failures, but rather as reminders that this is a journey, not a destination. And honestly, knowing that my health affects not just me, but the people I love, gives me the motivation to keep going.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Victoria Petrov: In the past two years, I've been managing some ongoing issues with my back, which I think are related to the long hours I spend sitting at my desk while working on projects. It started as a mild discomfort, but over time, it became more pronounced, especially after I began taking on more responsibilities at the nonprofit. I saw a physical therapist, and we worked on strengthening exercises and posture adjustments, which have helped quite a bit. I also started using a standing desk, which has made a noticeable difference. While it's not a major health issue, it's something I have to be mindful of every day. I've learned to take more breaks, stretch regularly, and remind myself to move throughout the day. It's a small but important reminder that even the things we take for granted—like being able to stand or sit comfortably—can be affected by how we live our lives. I'm grateful for the support of my doctor and the tools I've found to manage it, and I'm committed to keeping it under control so I can continue doing the work I love.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Victoria Petrov: Honestly, my back issues haven't really gotten in the way of my work or my ability to care for my family, but they have reminded me of how important it is to take care of myself. I've had to be more intentional about pacing myself, especially when I'm juggling projects or planning events. There were a few times when I pushed through the pain because I didn't want to let anyone down, but I've learned that pushing through isn't always the best choice. I've had to say 'no' to some things, or ask for help when I need it, and that's been a bit of a shift for me. I used to think that being strong meant never showing weakness, but now I see that being strong also means knowing when to rest and when to ask for support. My husband has been incredibly understanding, and I've also leaned on my faith community for encouragement. It's not perfect, but I'm learning to balance my responsibilities with my health in a way that honors both.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Victoria Petrov: Over the past year, I've felt a deep sense of gratitude and contentment in my life, even as there have been moments of challenge and reflection. Professionally, I've been proud of the work I've done with the nonprofit, especially in expanding our cultural exchange programs to include more voices from underrepresented communities. It's been rewarding to see the impact of our efforts, whether it's through a young person discovering a new language or a family finding common ground through shared experiences. At the same time, I've also had to confront some personal challenges, like the ongoing back issues I mentioned earlier, which have reminded me to slow down and be more present in my daily life. On a more emotional level, I've been reflecting a lot on my roots—my childhood in Moscow, my time in Prague, and the journey that brought me to Naperville. I've been reconnecting with parts of my heritage, learning more about Russian traditions, and even teaching some of them to my husband, Alex. It's been a beautiful way to honor where I came from while building a life here. I've also been feeling more connected to my faith community, especially through the Orthodox-Christian traditions that have become a cornerstone of my identity. There have been times when I've felt the weight of the world, especially with the global tensions and cultural divides that seem to be growing, but I try to hold onto the hope that through dialogue, understanding, and compassion, we can find ways to bridge those gaps. Overall, I feel like I'm in a good place, even if it's not always easy. I'm learning to embrace the ebb and flow of life, and I'm grateful for the people, experiences, and moments that continue to shape me.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 16 to 20, I realize how much my health and well-being have become a priority in my life, especially as I've grown older and more aware of the importance of balance. Discussing my daily routines and the changes I've made—like morning walks with Alex, yoga, and mindful eating—has reminded me of how small, intentional choices can have a big impact on my overall health. It's also brought up the challenges of staying consistent, especially when life gets busy or when I'm tempted to slip back into old habits. The conversation about my back issues and how they've affected my work and personal life made me more aware of the need to listen to my body and not push through pain just to keep going. I've come to see that health isn't just about avoiding illness—it's about living with intention, care, and gratitude. And knowing that my health affects not just me, but the people I love, gives me the motivation to keep making better choices every day.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Victoria Petrov: I think it's important to be honest about the emotional challenges I've faced, even if I haven't spoken about them much before. There have been times when I've felt a quiet sadness or a sense of isolation, especially when I'm working late or when the weight of the world feels too heavy to carry. I don't think I've ever been diagnosed with clinical depression or anxiety, but there have been moments when I've struggled with feeling overwhelmed or disconnected from the people around me. I've learned to recognize those feelings for what they are—signals that I need to pause, breathe, and reconnect with what truly matters. My faith has been a great anchor for me during those times, and so has my husband, who always knows when to offer a listening ear or a quiet presence. I've also found solace in the small, everyday moments—like tending to my garden, reading a book, or simply sharing a cup of tea with Alex. I believe that everyone has their own way of coping, and for me, it's about finding balance between the challenges of life and the things that bring me peace.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Victoria Petrov: For my family, the past year has been a mix of growth, connection, and quiet reflection. My husband, Alex, has been incredibly supportive, not just in my work but also in helping us both find balance in our lives. He's taken on more of the household responsibilities, which has allowed me to focus on my projects and also take the time I need to rest and heal. We've been making an effort to spend more quality time together—whether it's cooking meals at home, going on weekend hikes, or simply sitting on the porch and talking about our dreams. Our faith has also been a source of strength for both of us, especially during moments when the world feels uncertain. We've been attending more church events and participating in community service, which has deepened our sense of purpose. As for my mother, she's been doing well in Russia, though she misses us. She's staying active, gardening, and even started learning English through online classes, which she says is helping her feel more connected to our lives here. It's heartwarming to see her embrace change, even at her age. And my sister, Nadia, has been a constant source of encouragement, even from afar. She's been helping me with some of my projects through her teaching connections in Moscow, which has been a beautiful way for us to stay linked despite the distance. Overall, I feel like my family has been a steady foundation for me, reminding me that no matter how busy or challenging life gets, I'm never truly alone.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Victoria Petrov: For me, religion is not just a part of my life—it's the foundation upon which I build my sense of purpose, identity, and connection to the world. Growing up in a Russian household, Orthodox-Christian faith was woven into every aspect of our lives, from the way we celebrated holidays to the values we were taught. Even after moving to the United States, that faith has remained a constant, a source of comfort and guidance through both the joys and challenges of life. It's what helps me find meaning in the little things, like the morning prayers I say before starting my day or the way I approach my work with a sense of service and humility. My faith also strengthens my relationships, especially with my husband, Alex, who has come to embrace the traditions and rituals that are so important to me. Through our shared faith, we've built a life that feels rooted and whole, even in the midst of a fast-paced, ever-changing world. I don't always have all the answers, but I know that my faith gives me the strength to keep going, to stay connected to what truly matters, and to believe in the possibility of goodness in people and in the world.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Victoria Petrov: I do use social media, though not as extensively as some of my friends. I have a Facebook account where I stay in touch with family, especially my mother and sister back in Russia. It's been a lifeline for us, allowing us to share photos, updates, and even video calls when we can't meet in person. I also follow a few pages related to my work in cultural exchange and international relations, which helps me stay informed about events and opportunities in the field. I'm not really into Instagram or TikTok, as I find those platforms a bit too fast-paced for my taste. That said, I do use LinkedIn occasionally for professional networking, especially when I'm looking for collaborators or volunteers for our nonprofit projects. Social media, for me, is more about staying connected to the people I care about and the causes I believe in, rather than keeping up with trends or the latest viral content. It's a tool, but I try not to let it take over my time or my peace of mind.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Victoria Petrov: Honestly, I haven't relied much on social media for emotional or financial support, but I can see how it might help others. For me, emotional support has always come from my family, my faith community, and the people I've built relationships with over the years. When I've gone through tough times, like after my father passed away or when I was struggling with my back issues, it was the people I knew in person—my husband, my mother, my friends at church, or even my coworkers at the nonprofit—who offered me comfort and practical help. That said, I do recognize the power of online communities, especially for people who may not have the same support systems in place. I've seen how some of my friends use Facebook groups or forums to find encouragement, share resources, or even raise funds for causes they care about. I just prefer to keep my emotional support more personal and grounded in the relationships I've nurtured over time. It's not that I don't see the value in these platforms, but for me, they're more of a supplement than a primary source of strength.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 21 to 25, I realize how much my health and emotional well-being have become intertwined with the rhythms of my daily life and the support systems I've built around me. Talking about my back issues reminded me of the importance of listening to my body and not pushing through pain just to keep up with the demands of work or life. It's a lesson I'm still learning, but one that has brought me closer to understanding the balance between responsibility and self-care. Discussing my emotional challenges—those quiet moments of sadness or isolation—has also helped me see how deeply connected my mental health is to my faith, my relationships, and the small, meaningful routines I've created for myself. I've come to understand that it's okay to feel overwhelmed or disconnected at times, and that seeking support—whether from my husband, my faith community, or even the simple act of tending to my garden—is not a weakness, but a necessary part of living with intention and grace. These reflections have deepened my gratitude for the people and practices that help me stay grounded, even when life feels heavy.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Victoria Petrov: In the past year, I've noticed a shift in my levels of stress and worry, especially as I've taken on more responsibilities at the nonprofit and navigated the challenges of balancing work, faith, and family. There were times when I felt overwhelmed, particularly when planning large events or dealing with the ongoing strain on my back. But I've been learning to manage that stress through intentional coping strategies. One of the most important has been leaning more heavily on my faith—attending more services, participating in prayer groups, and finding comfort in the rituals that ground me. I've also started journaling more regularly, which helps me process my thoughts and emotions in a way that feels safe and constructive. Another change has been how I approach my time with my husband, Alex. We've made a conscious effort to carve out moments of stillness together, whether it's a quiet evening walk or just sitting in silence with a cup of tea. These small acts of presence have been incredibly grounding. I've also found that staying connected with my mother through video calls and sharing stories from our lives has helped ease some of the loneliness that can come with being far from home. Overall, I'm learning that stress isn't something to be eliminated, but something to be met with grace, patience, and the support of the people and practices that matter most to me.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Victoria Petrov: In terms of making ends meet, I'd say our monthly budget is pretty balanced, though it requires careful planning. Our biggest expenses last month were related to housing—rent and utilities, which take up a significant portion of our income. We also have regular expenses for groceries, especially since I've been trying to eat more healthily and incorporate more fresh produce into our meals. Another major expense is my car payment, as we rely on it for commuting to work, volunteering, and running errands. We also set aside money for my mother's occasional visits, which she does a couple of times a year, and for my sister's trips to the U.S. when she can afford it. I also contribute to a small savings account for when we decide to start a family, and we have some funds set aside for our faith-related activities, like donations to the church or community events. While we don't live extravagantly, I try to be mindful of where our money goes, and I'm grateful that my part-time job, combined with my husband's income, allows us to maintain a stable and peaceful life here in Naperville.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Victoria Petrov: Last month, our household spent around $3,200, which is pretty close to our usual monthly budget. We typically spend about $2,800 to $3,500 each month, depending on how many events we're planning for the nonprofit or if we have any unexpected expenses. The majority of that goes to our mortgage and utilities, which are around $1,200 combined. Groceries come next, usually about $600 to $700, especially since I've been trying to eat more healthily and buy fresh produce. Car payments and insurance are another $500 or so. We also set aside money for our faith-related activities, like donations to the church and occasional community events, which add up to about $200. I also contribute to a savings account for when we start a family, and we have some funds for travel or special occasions. While we don't have a lot of extra money, I feel grateful that we're able to live comfortably and support the work we care about.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Victoria Petrov: We rent our home here in Naperville. It's a two-story house on a quiet street in the Evergreen neighborhood, and while it's not the largest place, it feels like home. Renting has been a practical choice for us, especially since we're still in the early stages of planning for a family. It gives us the flexibility to adjust as our needs change, and it also allows us to allocate more of our budget toward our nonprofit work and savings. I like the sense of community that comes with renting in this area—many of our neighbors are long-time residents who know each other well, and it's comforting to feel part of something bigger than just ourselves.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Victoria Petrov: Over the past year, my bills have had their ups and downs, as they do for most people. In the winter months, our heating bill went up significantly, which is something I didn't expect when we first moved here. I had to adjust our budget a bit to cover that, which meant cutting back on some of the extras we usually enjoy, like dining out or buying new clothes. On the flip side, during the spring and summer, our electricity usage dropped because we were using less heat and more natural light, which helped us save a bit. Then there were the holidays—Christmas and Easter, in particular—when we had to set aside extra money for gifts, church donations, and family gatherings. I also noticed that when we hosted events for the nonprofit, like our cultural exchange dinners or community workshops, those sometimes added to our expenses, especially when it came to food, decorations, and guest speakers. But overall, I've learned to be more flexible with our budget and to plan ahead for these seasonal changes. It's not always easy, but it's a part of life that I've come to accept and manage with grace.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 26 to 30, I realize how deeply my family and faith have been a source of strength and stability in my life, especially during times of emotional or physical challenge. Talking about my family reminded me of how much love and support I have in my life—my husband, Alex, who is always there for me, my mother, who continues to be a pillar of encouragement from afar, and my sister, Nadia, who shares in my journey even from Moscow. It's comforting to know that no matter how busy or stressed I get, I have people who care about me and want to see me thrive. Discussing my use of social media also made me think about how I stay connected to the people I love. While I don't rely on platforms like Instagram or Twitter for emotional support, I do find value in Facebook for staying in touch with family and sharing updates about my work. It's a reminder that even in a digital world, the most meaningful connections are still the ones we build in person, through shared experiences, faith, and love.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Victoria Petrov: I do have a savings account, and I try to contribute to it regularly, even if it's just a small amount each month. For me, saving isn't just about preparing for the future—it's also about having a sense of security and control over my financial life. I've learned that even small, consistent contributions can add up over time, and I find comfort in knowing that there's a little cushion for unexpected expenses or opportunities. I also have a separate fund for when we decide to start a family, which I contribute to through my part-time income. While I don't save in the same way some people do, like investing in stocks or real estate, I believe that having a savings account gives me peace of mind and helps me stay focused on what truly matters—my work, my faith, and the people I love.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Victoria Petrov: In the last year, I've been saving for both a rainy day and for the future, especially as we start to think about having a family. I contribute a small but consistent amount to my general savings account each month, which I use for unexpected expenses or emergencies. I also have a separate fund that I'm building specifically for when we're ready to start a family—this includes savings for a down payment on a home, childcare costs, and other related expenses. I know that starting a family is a big step, and I want to be as prepared as I can be. Beyond that, I also try to save a little extra during times when my income is higher, like when I receive a bonus from the nonprofit or when I take on additional volunteer work that pays a small stipend. For me, saving is less about accumulating wealth and more about creating a sense of stability and peace of mind, knowing that I'm building a future that aligns with my values and the life I want to create with Alex.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Victoria Petrov: In my current occupation, I work part-time at a nonprofit organization here in Naperville that focuses on cultural exchange and community outreach. My role involves coordinating programs that bring together people from different backgrounds, whether through language classes, interfaith dialogues, or international guest speaker events. The most important activities in my work are building relationships, fostering understanding, and creating spaces where people can learn from one another. I spend a lot of time planning events, reaching out to community leaders, and working with volunteers to ensure that our programs are inclusive and impactful. One of the most rewarding parts of my job is seeing the connections that form between participants—whether it's a local family learning about a new culture or a young person discovering a passion for international relations. It's not always easy work, especially when dealing with limited resources or navigating the complexities of community dynamics, but I find it deeply fulfilling because it aligns with the values that have guided me since my early years. In many ways, my work is more of a calling than a job—it's a way to give back to the community that supported me when I needed it most, and to continue the journey of learning and growing that began in my childhood.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Victoria Petrov: I usually work around 20 to 25 hours each week, depending on the season and the number of events we're planning. Some weeks are busier than others, especially when we're organizing cultural exchange dinners or guest speaker series, which can take up more of my time. Other weeks are more relaxed, allowing me to focus on administrative tasks, community outreach, or even personal development. I appreciate the flexibility that part-time work gives me, as it allows me to balance my responsibilities with my faith, family, and personal well-being. It's not always easy to juggle everything, but I've learned to prioritize what matters most and to ask for help when I need it. My husband, Alex, has been a great support in that regard, and I'm grateful for the structure that my work provides without overwhelming me.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Victoria Petrov: No, I haven't had more than one job or business at the same time. I've always believed that quality of work matters more than quantity, and I wanted to make sure that whatever I was doing aligned with my values and purpose. That said, there were a few years when I took on some freelance writing projects on the side, especially when I was in college or just starting out in my career. Those were more about exploring my interests and earning extra money rather than being a full-time commitment. I found that juggling multiple jobs could be overwhelming, and I wanted to be fully present in whatever I was doing. Now, with my part-time role at the nonprofit, I feel like I'm exactly where I need to be—able to contribute meaningfully to my community while still having time for my family, faith, and personal growth.

And through it all, I'm reminded that I'm never truly alone, because I have the people, practices, and values that sustain me every day.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Victoria Petrov: In total, our household made around $4,200 in the past month. That includes my part-time income from the nonprofit, which is about $1,800, and my husband's salary from his IT job, which is roughly $2,400. We also received a small stipend from a volunteer project I was involved in, which added a few hundred dollars. While it's not a huge amount, it's enough to cover our expenses and even allow us to set aside a little for savings or unexpected needs. I've come to appreciate the stability of our income, especially knowing that it allows us to live with purpose and support the work we care about. It's not about wealth, but about having enough to live with dignity, care for one another, and contribute to the community in meaningful ways.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Victoria Petrov: I've been at my current job at the nonprofit for about five years now, and it's been a journey of growth and deepening purpose. The benefits of the job are modest but meaningful. We have health insurance coverage, which is essential for me, especially with my back issues, and we get a certain number of paid days off each year—enough to take short trips or just have some time to rest and recharge. The workplace itself is very supportive, and I appreciate the flexibility they offer, especially with my part-time schedule. There's also a strong sense of community among the staff and volunteers, which makes the work feel more like a shared mission than just a job. While I don't have the same benefits as someone in a full-time corporate position, I find that the intangible rewards—like knowing that my work helps bring people together and fosters understanding—are what truly sustain me. It's not about the perks, but about the impact we're able to make, even in small ways, that makes this job feel like a calling.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Victoria Petrov: My relationships at work are very positive and built on mutual respect and shared purpose. I have a great relationship with my manager, who is someone I deeply admire. She's been with the organization for many years and has a deep understanding of our mission. She's always been supportive of my growth, whether it's encouraging me to take on new projects or offering guidance when I'm feeling overwhelmed. I feel fortunate that she sees my contributions and trusts me with important responsibilities. As for my coworkers, we have a strong sense of camaraderie. We come from different backgrounds and have different experiences, but we're all united by the common goal of fostering understanding and connection within our community. I especially enjoy working with the volunteers, because they bring so much energy and passion to our programs. There's a real sense of teamwork and collaboration here, and I feel like I'm part of something meaningful. It's not always easy work, but knowing that I'm making a difference in people's lives makes it all worthwhile.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Victoria Petrov: My work schedule is pretty predictable, though there's some flexibility depending on the needs of the nonprofit. I usually work Monday through Friday, with mornings dedicated to administrative tasks, meetings, and planning, and afternoons spent in the community or with volunteers. The hours are generally from 9 a.m. to 1 p.m., but sometimes I stay a bit later if I'm preparing for an event or meeting with a guest speaker. What I appreciate most is that my manager trusts me to manage my time well, so I can often adjust my schedule if needed—whether it's starting a bit later in the morning or finishing up a bit later in the afternoon. This flexibility is especially helpful when I need to attend church services, spend time with my husband, or tend to my garden. It's not a rigid 9-to-5 job, and I think that balance is what makes it sustainable for me. I can still be present for the important things in my life while contributing meaningfully to the work I love.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Victoria Petrov: Overall, I feel content with my financial situation. It's not extravagant, but it's stable and allows us to live with purpose. I know that money isn't everything, and I've learned to be grateful for what we have rather than focusing on what we don't. My part-time job, combined with my husband's income, gives us the freedom to support our community, care for each other, and maintain a sense of peace in our daily lives. I also appreciate the fact that we're not burdened by debt or financial stress, which allows us to focus on what truly matters—our faith, our relationships, and the work we do to bring people together. There are days when I think about the future and wonder if we'll have more, but I've come to understand that happiness isn't tied to wealth. It's tied to connection, purpose, and the ability to live with integrity. I'm grateful for the life we've built, and I believe that as long as we continue to work together, support one another, and stay true to our values, we'll be just fine.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Victoria Petrov: Yes, both my parents worked for pay while I was growing up, though their roles were quite different. My father worked as a mechanic, which was his full-time job, and he was always very hands-on with our family life. He didn't have a formal education beyond high school, but he was a hard worker and took pride in his craft. My mother, on the other hand, had a graduate degree in literature and worked as a teacher for several years before she decided to focus more on our family. Even after that, she continued to be involved in educational programs and community initiatives, which is where her passion for learning and helping others truly shone. Both of them made sacrifices to provide for our family, and I think that's something I carry with me today. Their work shaped not only our financial stability but also the values I hold dear—hard work, education, and the importance of giving back to the community.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Victoria Petrov: My father worked as a mechanic at a local garage, and his most important duties involved repairing cars, maintaining equipment, and ensuring that everything ran smoothly. He had a deep understanding of how machines worked, and he took pride in his work, even though he didn't have formal training beyond high school. He was the kind of person who could fix anything with just a wrench and a bit of ingenuity. My mother, on the other hand, was a teacher for many years, and her most important activities involved not just instructing students in literature, but also inspiring them to think critically and creatively. She believed that education was a way to open doors, and she passed that belief on to me. Even after she left the classroom, she remained deeply involved in community education programs, often volunteering her time to help underprivileged children. Both of them, in their own ways, taught me the value of hard work, the importance of learning, and the power of giving back to others—lessons that have shaped the person I am today.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Victoria Petrov: My father worked at a small, family-owned garage in Moscow, which was a modest business but very much a part of the community. He was responsible for everything from basic car repairs to more complex engine work, and he often took on extra projects to help neighbors out. The business was run by a few local mechanics, and while it wasn't lucrative, it provided steady work and a sense of purpose. My mother, on the other hand, worked at a public school where she taught literature to high school students. She was passionate about her work and often stayed after class to help students with their essays or discuss books that inspired her. Even though she eventually left the classroom to focus more on our family, she never stopped believing in the power of education. She often said that teaching wasn't just about passing on knowledge—it was about planting seeds that would grow into something meaningful for the students and for the world. Both of their jobs, in their own ways, were about service and care, and that's something I carry with me every day.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Victoria Petrov: Looking a few years ahead, I hope to see my life continue to grow in the ways that matter most—deepening my work in cultural exchange, strengthening my family, and staying rooted in my faith. I hope that we'll have the opportunity to start a family, and that we'll be able to raise children who are curious, compassionate, and connected to both their Russian heritage and the world around them. I also hope to see our nonprofit continue to expand its impact, perhaps by reaching more communities and creating more opportunities for people to learn from one another. I don't know exactly what the future holds, but I do know that I want to live with intention, love, and purpose. I hope that in the years to come, I'll look back and see that I've made choices that honored who I am, who I've loved, and the values that have guided me all along.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Victoria Petrov: What I value the most in my life is connection—connection to my family, to my faith, and to the people and communities I serve through my work. I believe that life is not just about what we achieve, but about who we become through the relationships we nurture and the love we give. My mother taught me that education is a gift, but it's the people we meet along the way who truly shape us. My husband, Alex, has shown me what it means to love with patience and devotion. My faith reminds me that no matter how difficult life gets, there is always a reason to hope. And my work, though small in scale, gives me the chance to be part of something bigger than myself—to help others see the beauty in difference and the strength in unity. I value these things because they are the foundation of who I am, and I hope that in the years to come, I continue to live with gratitude for them.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a journey of reflection and gratitude. It has reminded me of how deeply interconnected my experiences, relationships, and values are. From my childhood in Moscow to my decision to study in Prague, each step of my life has been shaped by the people around me—my parents, my mentors, my friends, and my faith. I see now how much my mother's belief in education and my father's quiet strength have influenced the person I've become. The interview also brought back the importance of community, whether it's the neighborhood in Naperville where I feel safe and connected, or the people I work with at the nonprofit who share my passion for cultural exchange. I've come to realize that life is not about grand moments or dramatic turning points, but about the small, consistent choices we make every day—whether it's tending to my garden, saying a prayer in the morning, or choosing to listen to someone in need. This reflection has deepened my appreciation for the life I've built, and it has reminded me that I am exactly where I need to be, surrounded by love, purpose, and the people who have walked beside me all along.
